titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Attended a meeting of the Directors of the fire and marine insurance Office— Agreed upon a dividend, to be declared at the meeting of the Company to-morrow— Remainder of the day employed on my usual occupations at my Office and at home— Called with Mrs: Adams this Evening, at Dr: Welsh’s— He is still confined with the carbuncle on his thumb— But is recovering.— Read a few pages of the Astronomical Essays.

2. Mr: Peabody, and Mr: Ripley called at my house this morning.— There was, at 11. O’Clock a meeting of the proprietors of Neponset Bridge, at Whitcomb’s—which I attended— It was on a project to build a house for a Tavern, on the other side of the Bridge— A Committee was appointed to draw up a paper, and present to the proprietors for signature— To be reported at the annual meeting next Tuesday— I was but about an hour at my office— Mr: Riggs of Georgetown; who has just arrived in town dined with us— At 7. in the Evening there was a meeting of the Stockholders in the Fire and Marine Insurance Company; at which the President and Directors of the preceding year were re-chosen— Mr: Degrand called on me, at the close of the Evening, and supped with us.

3. I Bathed this morning with George, at the Platform near the new Baptist Church— The weather having become excessively warm; attended afterwards at my Office, where I found Mr: Everett, and Mr: Gallison— Mr: Loud was gone to Weymouth. This afternoon, I went with George out to my fathers at Quincy— Louisa Smith came in with Susan Adams, who is going to Atkinson, with Mr: Peabody— And when I return on Monday, Louisa is to go back, taking Abigail Shaw, to spend a month at my fathers— I found my father unwell with a severe cold.

4. Heard Mr: Bradford of Roxbury the two parts of the day.— The day was again excessively warm— A slight thunder-shower towards the Evening terminated a drought occasioned by five weeks without rain— It has burnt away all the verdure of the fields; and made many of the trees—as Linden’s—Poplars and Balm of Gilead, fall into the sear & yellow leaf. I read some astronomical papers— Mr: T. Greenleaf and Captn: Beale were at my father’s this Evening.

5. Returned to Boston this morning with George— At my Office sometime— Called at Mr: Dexter’s Office, but could not find him— Saw Mr: Quincy, and made an occasional settlement with him— The heat was so great that I could write nothing; and read very little— Great part of the afternoon I employed in teaching George— Evening—attended with the Ladies a large party at Mr: S. A. Otis’s.

6. I completed the perusal of the first Philippick of Demosthenes in the original— Mr: Hall called upon me at my Office— Read something in Goguet’s Origin of Laws; an English Translation— We were invited to a party this Evening, at Mr: H. G. Otis’s— But a thunder-storm came up, which prevented our going— I read but little in the afternoon or Evening. The heat first, and afterwards a heaviness amounting almost to stupefaction, which I often experience immediately after thunder-showers scarcely allowed me to read. I gave however some time to George.

7. I began this morning a Translation of the first Olynthiac of Demosthenes, in Mountenay’s edition. At my Office, read part of Sir William Jones’s Sacontala— Mr: Hall called upon me again—with some papers, which I read— Club this Evening at Mr: Emerson’s— Not very fully attended— There was a party at Mr: Foster’s, our neighbour, where Mrs: A. and Catherine pass’d the Evening.

8. Almost the whole day employed in reading— Began the second volume of Demosthenes—Leland’s— And gave a couple of hours to George’s french lessons— Walking in the Evening in the Mall, we met Mr: Verplank junior of New-York, who was coming to call on us. He returned and pass’d the remainder of the Evening with us.

9. The day was employed as usual, at my Office and at home—reading Demosthenes and Goguet—endeavouring to learn something myself, and to teach something to George— I called upon Mr: Verplank— Mr: L. Foster and his Sister pass’d the Evening with us.

10. Mr: Verplank of New-York, Mr: Isaac Smith, and the young Gentlemen in my Office, Messrs: Everett, Gallison and Loud, dined with us— Mr: Verplank pass’d the afternoon and Evening with us— Mr: L. Foster, and Mr: Kinloch also pass’d the Evening here. Lady Temple and her family, met with an accident to their carriage in passing by our house, and came in for a few minutes. The day was thus engross’d entirely by company.

11. Heard Mr: Bancroft of Worcester, both parts of the day, at Mr: Emerson’s— His pronunciation is intolerable; and his Sermons were very ordinary.— Mr: Shaw was here this afternoon— In the Evening we read something in Jones’s Essays—my wife is the reader, for in the state of my eyes, I dare not read by candle-light— I read Tillotson’s sermons 141. and 142. which finish the 6th: volume of his works— George got through the first volume of Berquin.

12. Mr: DeGrand called upon me to bathe this Morning, but we found it too late for the tide— Forenoon at my Office; and with Mr: Hall examining papers. Afternoon and Evening at home— Mr: H. Erskine called to see us this day.

13. Mr: Aspinwall engaged the lower room of my House in Court-Street for one year— We agreed upon the terms, and the lease is to be drawn to-morrow.— Mr: Hall was again part of the morning at my Office— My brother was in town, from Quincy— Mr: Verplanck spent the Evening with us— The day otherwise was employed at my usual occupations.
14. I was late at my Office this morning, because employed longer than usual at home upon Demosthenes— Club this Evening, at Mr: Gray’s, and was well attended. I took Mr: Verplanck with me.

15. My occupations are now so regular, as scarcely to present a material variety from day to day— Mr: Everett spent the Evening with us— Catherine went with Mr: L. Foster and Mr: Verplanck to a ball at Mr: Dexter’s— Mr: Riggs also called here twice— He is to go for Georgetown on his return home, to-morrow morning.

16. Executed leases of my front lower rooms in Court-Street for one year from 1. October to Mr: D. S. Greenough, & Mr: T. Aspinwall. Began a translation of Demosthenes 2. Olynthiac. I read also a Greek Grammar on a new plan, by Jones—and Goguet’s Origin of Laws, in a good English Translation— In the Evening we continue to read Jones’s Astronomical Essays.

17. In the morning, I met in the Street Mr: John Coles— Mr: White attended at my Office— So that I have now four Students with me— Mr: J. Gardner called at my Office this forenoon, and in the Evening walked with me in the Mall; where he mentioned to me a variety of curious facts relating to certain political intrigues.— My brother Charles’s widow, and her youngest daughter Abigail arrived at my house this Evening from New-York.— I marked this Afternoon the place of the setting Sun, from the top of my house; for the purpose of observing the extent of its declination North and South— I therefore begin this notice at the time of the Equinox.

18. Heard Mr: Ripley of Concord, Morning and afternoon— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 143. 144. the first in the seventh volume. Still continuing the series upon the attributes of God. Mr: Verplanck and Mr: Joy junr: called on us— My brother came to bring his wife to town this afternoon, and was a few minutes at my house. He returned to Quincy this Night— Catherine spent the Evening at Mr: H. G. Otis’s— I called with Mrs: C. Adams and my wife, at Mr: William Smith’s— We were but a short time there, my wife, being very unwell, and obliged to come home— Observed the sun about ten minutes risen; but it was too late to mark its position in the horizon— It set at no perceptible distance from its position last Evening

19. Mr: Erskine and Mr: Stirling pass’d the Evening with us—which Mr: De Grand also did— My studies with George, were consequently abridged— I observed the rising of the Sun this morning, and its relative position, upon my house— Had I not been detained by company, a thunder shower, which was forming at the time of Sunset, would have deprived me of the means of seeing it set.— My tenant Mr: King was also at my house this Evening— I began to read Leland’s Translation of Eschines against Ctesiphon. My wife, and Catherine were both very unwell.

20. I dined at Mr H. G. Otis’s, with a small company of Gentlemen. Among whom were Mr Erskine, Mr: Stirling, and Mr: Verplanck. My mother came into town, intending to return at Night, with Mrs: Charles Adams, and her daughter, to Quincy— But the weather proving bad, she concluded to pass the Night here. The Sun rose clear, but the greatest part of the day was rainy— I made an insurance on my next house, at the mutual insurance office.

21. The day was windy, cloudy and very cold— We commenced our fires— In the afternoon, my mother returned home with Mrs: C. Adams, and Abigail.— Club this Evening at Dr: Howard’s— It was not very fully attended— Read something in Jones’s Essays— And I continue employed on Demosthenes.

22. Met this morning in the Street, Mr: Bacon, the member of Congress, and found him anxious with regard to public affairs. Dr: Fothergill of Philadelphia called this Evening to see me— Spent the Evening, with the Ladies at Mr: P. Foster’s; where Mrs: T. B. Adams is passing the week.

23. Mr: T. Greenleaf called at my Office this Morning; to attend a meeting of the Directors of Neponset-Bridge, to-morrow afternoon; on a proposal from Mr: Quincy.— Mr: Bacon—Dr: Waterhouse and his son Andrew; Mr: Everett, Mr: White and Mr: Loud, dined with us— Evening pass’d reading Jones’s Essays— My neighbour and Tenant Mr: Reinhart died this afternoon; after a severe illness of about a fortnight.

24. My father came into Town this morning, with Mr: Quincy, and after passing an hour here, left us to go and dine with Mr: Pomeroy, at Brighton— This afternoon, I walk’d out as far as Neponset Bridge, a little beyond which I was taken up by my father’s Carriage, which was carrying home Mrs: T. B. Adams, and her two children; and in which was my George. when we came to my father’s we found Mr: & Mrs: Black there— My father came in a few minutes after us— The house is full.

25. Heard Mr: Charles Lowell, morning and afternoon— The remainder of the day was employed chiefly in reading; but without any particular direction— The days are so shortened, that the time left in which I can read is very much abridged.

26. Returned to Boston this morning in the Stage— Attended at my Office— Mr: Bacon called there, and told me it was the wish of the republicans, to hold me up as the candidate to represent this District in Congress at the approaching Election, which from a variety of considerations I declined. The decisive inducement to me is my friendship for Mr: Quincy, the present Representative, and my belief that he will not unite in the combination against the Union, and Independence of the Country— Mr: Bacon urged me with great earnestness to accept, but I told him I was irrevocably determined— I spent part of the Evening at Dr: Welsh’s—where I found Mrs: G. Payne, and Miss Buckminster.— Catherine attended a Ball at Mr: H. G. Otis’s.

27. I saw Mr: G. Blake this morning, and renewed my refusal to stand as a Candidate at the approaching Election— Mr: Bacon had yesterday, proposed to me on finding my determination made, that the offer should be publicly made to me, leaving it to me either to accept or decline— At the first suggestion of this it had occurred to me, that this circumstance would give me an opportunity to declare, in declining my adherence to all the principles for which I have contended, and by which I have lost the favour of the federal party— As a mark of strong confidence from the opposite party there might also be some gratification to my personal feelings. I had however before parting from Mr: Bacon strongly inclined to the conclusion that it would be best that the offer should not be made to me at-all— After leaving him, on further reflection this conclusion became the more decisive upon me— For, as to the personal gratification, I saw my duty to set that aside, entirely— And as to the opportunity of manifesting my adherence to my principles, it is not now necessary, since I have done nothing to induce a suspicion of my having deserted them; and if occasion should arise requiring such an assurance from me to the public, nothing can be easier than to find, or to make an opportunity to do it. There appeared also to me to be forcible reasons against my consenting to have a public offer made to me, with a predetermination to decline it, known to the leaders of the party, by whom the offer would be made, before they should make it— There seems to be a littleness in such a preconcerted offer and refusal, which ought alone to discard it as a mode of proceeding— It would probably promote Quincy’s election; but he does not need it, to secure that object, and it would be an improper way of aiding him; since it must be at the expence of those who are manifesting this unlimited confidence in me— It would also be no cordial to the feelings, of the Candidate who may be substituted in my stead—who has also strong claims to delicacy of treatment from me. These motives had presented themselves to me in so strong a light, that I was apprehensive Mr: Bacon might have considered my answer on this point as so far indecisive that the offer might be made me— I therefore called at his lodgings last Evening; to make my answer perfectly explicit. He was not at his lodgings, and this morning left town. I therefore called on Blake, as one of the central Committee of that party, and found that from Mr: Bacon’s report to them, he had understood me perfectly, as inclining against the offer, but not decisively; so that they would certainly make it.— I therefore explicitly declared my wish that the offer should not be made; and explained my reasons to Blake to his satisfaction, and they will not make it— Their Candidate will be Eustis.— I met also Mr: Hall, and Mr: Gorham at the Fire and Marine Insurance Office, on business.

28. Dined with Mr: G. Blake, and a small company of Gentlemen—A Son of Genl: Smith and a Mr: Hollings of Baltimore—A Mr: Jones, an Englishman—Mr: D. Davis Mr: R. Sullivan, Mr: Minot, and Mr: W. Jarvis were also of the company.— Club this Evening at Dr: Kirkland’s— Sufficiently full.— This is an interruption almost total to my studies—

29. I had my books put up in a couple of additional shelves— But they are still in a very confused situation, and so must remain— A library is a thing too burdensome for poverty and a vagrant life. I was at my Office in the morning— But a great part of the afternoon by a Mr: Jenkins, a projector, who has or pretends to have a new system for teaching children to write— He has a multitude of recommendatory certificates, and wanted mine— But I did not understand the subject enough to certify any thing about it— I saw the man’s hand writing was itself very bad—that he was extremely illiterate, and was apparently not very temperate.— He kept me however nearly two hours— Charlotte Foster was here; afternoon and Evening— And Mr: De Grand afterwards— I read to the Ladies part of Scott’s Marmion.

30. Finished the Translation of the second Olynthiac of Demosthenes— Mr: Dexter called upon me this Evening; and had some conversation with me respecting the insurance question, for the Fire and Marine Office. He considers the case as desperate, and I shall therefore be disposed to give it up.

Day. The same as the last month; excepting the change of some books that I read— Instead of the interlinear version of Mountenay’s Demosthenes, I have made a literal translation of the first and second Olynthiacs.— I have not time enough for my own studies; and I devote perhaps too much to those of my son George.
